Now we've got the story of one woman's journey home to East Africa after 25 years in exile.
I left Ethiopia in 1976, two years after the army deposed Emperor Haile Selassie had set a powerful wave of turmoil and state-sponsored violence crashing across the country.
Along with countless others, my parents were swept up in that wave and soon, the life they had built together had been completely washed away.

In the summer of 1976, my parents, my sisters and I found ourselves abruptly deposited in the United States, stripped of our possessions and expectations, and left to start over financially, professionally, emotionally.
Rebecca Haile's parents fled Ethiopia two years after a brutal coup.
Her father, a leading academic in the capital Addis Ababa, was shot by army troops.
The bullet left him paralyzed.
Rebecca and her family eventually settled in a small Midwestern town.
She adjusted to her new life in America, but it wasn't easy.
Central Minnesota, when we got there in 1976, there really were no minorities to speak of, let alone Ethiopians.
So I think assimilation was really the only option available to us.
And fortunately for me and for my sister, we had learned English earlier so we didn't have language barrier.

The decision ultimately to go back came as I grew into an adult, wanting to test my memories that I had kept - I left when I was 11 so I really had very clear childhood memories - test them against the modern life to see the country that I had left.

I was thinking a lot about culture and identity mediation, I mean, I am very American but, of course, my core, my family, my values are a function of having grown up in an Ethiopian family and my extended family is all Ethiopian and many of them are still there.
Twenty-five years later, Rebecca Haile returned to the country of her birth with what she calls all her Americanisms in tow.
She chronicles her trip in a new book.
It's called ""Held At A Distance: My Rediscovery of Ethiopia."" She shared her journey with NPR's Tony Cox.
My first entree into the country was through my family, my remaining family.

So there was no holding myself at a distance from that family.
And because I was able to enter back in through their protection as it were, it was really a wonderful experience to see these family members that I had missed for so long.
